Replace Instances with Code
LIFE726
Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Clinical trials are the key final step to translate medical research into the benefit of patients. As new therapies have become available in the treatment of cancer, the methods used in trials have also evolved. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is designed to develop the knowledge and understanding of the design, delivery, and assessment of clinical trials in cancer. This module will cover fundamentals of clinical trials and designs, as well as the challenges that arise at each of these strategies. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, case-based learning tutorials and workshops. The lectures will convey basic knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work, in equal measure. The students will have case-based learning tutorials on critical appraisal of literature and clinical trials design. There will also be a workshop with a clinical trials coordinator. The module will be assessed via two assessments consisting of a poster presentation, based on a chosen lecture topic, and a written assessment, in which students will be required to design a clinical trial.
Educational Aims
This module is designed to provide the students insights into how cancer clinical trials are designed and what strategies are to be considered whilst designing and executing a clinical trial. In order to achieve this, the students will be introduced to key concepts in this field, followed by lectures on how translational research is linked to clinical trials, with respect to study design, as well as regulatory requirements. The assessments in this module will enable students to critically appraise published clinical trials and systematic reviews. The module will have several case-based learning tutorials and workshops, all of which will enable the students to independently design a clinical trial to address a clinically important question.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Clinical trials are the key final step to translate medical research into the benefit of patients. The Liverpool Clinical Trials Unit is one of the largest in the UK, running a wide variety of surgical and oncology studies, that range from phase I studies to large, practice-changing phase III studies, as well as more novel trial designs. Since new therapies have become available in the treatment of cancer, the methods used in clinical trials have also evolved. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is aimed at developing the knowledge and understanding of decisions affecting the design, delivery and assessment of clinical trials. This module will be taught by clinicians, researchers, statisticians and trial methodologists at the Liverpool Trials Unit, and cover fundamentals of clinical trials and designs, as well as the challenges that arise at each of these strategies. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is ideal for current in-service health professionals looking to broaden their role in the design, management, analysis and reporting of clinical trials. It is also suited to those wishing to gain an understanding of clinical trials. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, case-based learning tutorials and workshops, and assessed via a poster presentation and a written assessment, involving the design of a clinical trial.
Outline Syllabus
Clinical Epidemiology/ Evidence based medicine - Approaches and Challenges

Cancer Clinical trials - Study design and Introduction to statistical analysis/methodology

Cancer Clinical trials - Concepts and Management

Oncology Surgical trials - Design and Execution

Biomarker development and validation for Cancer Clinical trials

Translational research linked to clinical trial endpoints: Regulatory requirements and link to data quality

Ethical issues emerging from the design and execution of Cancer Clinical trials
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: Lectures will cover core curriculum topics. Research-focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content.

Scheduled Tutorials: Staff-led Case-Based Learning tutorials, which will introduce students, in interactive learning sessions/ group discussions, to clinical trials design in different cancer types.

Workshop: A workshop will be conducted by a Liverpool Clinical Trials coordinator to educate and train students in the designing of a mock-clinical trial.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Curriculum 2021 and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme that we have designed, in which all learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. Research-led teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching, as the module is taught by experts in their field. This module contributes to an MSc in Cancer Biology and Therapy, which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and provide ample scope for employability. The teaching approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by taking part in Case-Based Learning and designing a mock-Clinical Trial.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments –

The first assessment consists of a poster presentation, based on a chosen lecture topic. This will assess the students’ ability to convey, discuss and defend complex scientific ideas, relevant to their degree, to their peers. This assessment will aid in the development of communication and critical thinking skills, in line with C2021 Hallmarks. Assessment weighting: 30%. This assessment is not anonymous due its nature.

The second assessment will be a written assessment in which students will be required to design a clinical trial. This assessment will comprise an analysis of the theoretical and practical work performed in the module, designing a clinical trial. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of clinical research; digital fluency and active learning. The report will allow students to demonstrate a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of the essential concepts in their chosen field of study – authentic Assessment. Assessment weighting: 70%. This assessment is anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Deliveries

Liverpool campus
Semester 2


Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Assess the different cancer clinical trial strategies and designs
 LO2 Justify appropriate courses of action to ensure good practice is set out and adhered to in given cancer clinical trial situations
 LO3 Analyse and interpret cancer clinical trial data
 LO4 Critique and appraise published cancer clinical trials and systematic reviews
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome

 S2 Develop critical thinking
 S3 Digital fluency

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

Replace Instances with Code
LIFE726
Notes
The new module was developed as a result of a strategic decision which, following research, showed that new MSc programmes should be developed in the FHLS. We aim to offer a PGT Portfolio of a scope and quality that is comparable to competitor Russell Group Institutions, aligned to our strategic ambitions.

Overview

Overview
Clinical trials are the key final step to translate medical research into the benefit of patients. As new therapies have become available in the treatment of cancer, the methods used in trials have also evolved. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is designed to develop the knowledge and understanding of the design, delivery, and assessment of clinical trials in cancer. This module will cover fundamentals of clinical trials and designs, as well as the challenges that arise at each of these strategies. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, case-based learning tutorials and workshops. The lectures will convey basic knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work, in equal measure. The students will have case-based learning tutorials on critical appraisal of literature and clinical trials design. There will also be a workshop with a clinical trials coordinator. The module will be assessed via two assessments consisting of a poster presentation, based on a chosen lecture topic, and a written assessment, in which students will be required to design a clinical trial.
Educational Aims
This module is designed to provide the students insights into how cancer clinical trials are designed and what strategies are to be considered whilst designing and executing a clinical trial. In order to achieve this, the students will be introduced to key concepts in this field, followed by lectures on how translational research is linked to clinical trials, with respect to study design, as well as regulatory requirements. The assessments in this module will enable students to critically appraise published clinical trials and systematic reviews. The module will have several case-based learning tutorials and workshops, all of which will enable the students to independently design a clinical trial to address a clinically important question.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Clinical trials are the key final step to translate medical research into the benefit of patients. The Liverpool Clinical Trials Unit is one of the largest in the UK, running a wide variety of surgical and oncology studies, that range from phase I studies to large, practice-changing phase III studies, as well as more novel trial designs. Since new therapies have become available in the treatment of cancer, the methods used in clinical trials have also evolved. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is aimed at developing the knowledge and understanding of decisions affecting the design, delivery and assessment of clinical trials. This module will be taught by clinicians, researchers, statisticians and trial methodologists at the Liverpool Trials Unit, and cover fundamentals of clinical trials and designs, as well as the challenges that arise at each of these strategies. The module in Cancer Clinical Trials is ideal for current in-service health professionals looking to broaden their role in the design, management, analysis and reporting of clinical trials. It is also suited to those wishing to gain an understanding of clinical trials. The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, case-based learning tutorials and workshops, and assessed via a poster presentation and a written assessment, involving the design of a clinical trial.
Outline Syllabus
Clinical Epidemiology/ Evidence based medicine - Approaches and Challenges

Cancer Clinical trials - Study design and Introduction to statistical analysis/methodology

Cancer Clinical trials - Concepts and Management

Oncology Surgical trials - Design and Execution

Biomarker development and validation for Cancer Clinical trials

Translational research linked to clinical trial endpoints: Regulatory requirements and link to data quality

Ethical issues emerging from the design and execution of Cancer Clinical trials
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: Lectures will cover core curriculum topics. Research-focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content.

Scheduled Tutorials: Staff-led Case-Based Learning tutorials, which will introduce students, in interactive learning sessions/ group discussions, to clinical trials design in different cancer types.

Workshop: A workshop will be conducted by a Liverpool Clinical Trials coordinator to educate and train students in the designing of a mock-clinical trial.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Curriculum 2021 and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme that we have designed, in which all learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. Research-led teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching, as the module is taught by experts in their field. This module contributes to an MSc in Cancer Biology and Therapy, which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and provide ample scope for employability. The teaching approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by taking part in Case-Based Learning and designing a mock-Clinical Trial.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments –

The first assessment consists of a poster presentation, based on a chosen lecture topic. This will assess the students’ ability to convey, discuss and defend complex scientific ideas, relevant to their degree, to their peers. This assessment will aid in the development of communication and critical thinking skills, in line with C2021 Hallmarks. Assessment weighting: 30%. This assessment is not anonymous due its nature.

The second assessment will be a written assessment in which students will be required to design a clinical trial. This assessment will comprise an analysis of the theoretical and practical work performed in the module, designing a clinical trial. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of clinical research; digital fluency and active learning. The report will allow students to demonstrate a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of the essential concepts in their chosen field of study – authentic Assessment. Assessment weighting: 70%. This assessment is anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”

 LO2 Justify appropriate courses of action to ensure good practice is set out and adhered to in given cancer clinical trial situations
 LO3 Analyse and interpret cancer clinical trial data
 LO4 Critique and appraise published cancer clinical trials and systematic reviews

Translational research linked to clinical trial endpoints: Regulatory requirements and link to data quality

Ethical issues emerging from the design and execution of Cancer Clinical trials
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: Lectures will cover core curriculum topics. Research-focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content.

Scheduled Tutorials: Staff-led Case-Based Learning tutorials, which will introduce students, in interactive learning sessions/ group discussions, to clinical trials design in different cancer types.

Workshop: A workshop will be conducted by a Liverpool Clinical Trials coordinator to educate and train students in the designing of a mock-clinical trial.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Curriculum 2021 and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module, as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme that we have designed, in which all learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. Research-led teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching, as the module is taught by experts in their field. This module contributes to an MSc in Cancer Biology and Therapy, which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and provide ample scope for employability. The teaching approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by taking part in Case-Based Learning and designing a mock-Clinical Trial.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments –

The first assessment consists of a poster presentation, based on a chosen lecture topic. This will assess the students’ ability to convey, discuss and defend complex scientific ideas, relevant to their degree, to their peers. This assessment will aid in the development of communication and critical thinking skills, in line with C2021 Hallmarks. Assessment weighting: 30%. This assessment is not anonymous due its nature.

The second assessment will be a written assessment in which students will be required to design a clinical trial. This assessment will comprise an analysis of the theoretical and practical work performed in the module, designing a clinical trial. The assessment strategy will assess meaningful and integrated application of clinical research; digital fluency and active learning. The report will allow students to demonstrate a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of the essential concepts in their chosen field of study – authentic Assessment. Assessment weighting: 70%. This assessment is anonymous.

Reassessment strategy: Resit questions will have the same format as the original assessment and will take place in the reassessment window and will be capped at 50%

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
